content: what's up guys I'm back episode 5 I know it's been a while since the last video
but hey is the holidays like busy also I decided that if I'm going to be doing
this channel thing I got to get some real video editing software i movie's
not cutting it so I got some Final Cut Pro been spending some time learning how
to use it and this is the first video using it so hopefully it all works out
anyway what are we making today something refreshing we're making these
super cool water feature cave tiles okay can you guys see can you see this
up hold on these things are super nice looking maybe even a little too good for
game use but they're really easy to make I got a super cool simple trick how to
carve a moat in such a way that doesn't use very much artificial water keeping
costs really low simple paint job really simple build very fun looks good so yeah
if you guys want to see how we make them let's go over to the craft table and
whip one up so start off by carving out a cave tile
from pink or blue foam you can see how we do this on Episode one trace out the
exact shape you want for your water feature the outline matters as it will
be followed exactly in the next step grab some clear nail polish and brush it
onto the foam surface this will melt the polystyrene in a really cool way the
melt line won't bleed at all so it will give you a nice clean edge which is why
you should draw that shape out exactly as you want it you can see here that it
works really quickly the nice thing about this method is that it makes a
very shallow recess after the first pass you might decide that you'd like some of
the areas to be deeper you can go over it again with more nail polish that'll
melt it even further but you have to do this fairly quickly after the first coat
once the nail polish has dried additional coats won't cause the foam to
melt any further after the second pass the depressions
get a bit deeper and the texture gets more extreme you can do this to suit
your style after a few minutes the foam gets nice and hard again
but after this point you won't be able to melt it any further once you're happy
with the melted area you can begin to texture the rest of the surface to match
your other tiles I'm using the same method I used in episode 1 basically I
just cover the entire surface with full-strength PVA glue I also added a
few drops inside the water area next shake on your construction sand I don't
go for full coverage just enough to give it a nice texture you can see here a few
of those larger rocks glued inside the water area it'll look good later once
everything is dry prime it out in black I prefer to paint the water before the
rest of the tile and I start with a dark blue I put this on fairly wet to make
sure that it gets into all the crevices while that dark blue is still wet I grab
some turquoise and start blending it in I just go around the edges avoiding the
middle this will give the illusion of some deeper parts in the middle of the
pond and again while everything's still wet I go with some light green and just
kind of randomly dab it in around the edges you'll then want to let this part
completely dry out before you move to the next step take that same turquoise
used earlier and just start dry brushing in to give everything some highlights
again you want to avoid the middle of the pond to keep that illusion of depth
now you can take some of that same green used earlier and again just kind of dab
it in randomly around the edges this will give the pond a bit of a look like
it has some algae in it it'll give the blue some variants and and just really
make everything look a little bit more interesting than just blue after you're
happy with your paint on the water area you can go ahead and paint out the rest
of the tile using whatever technique you've used on the rest of your tile
system here I just cover everything in a dark grey if you put in any of those
stones into the water make sure you don't forget to hit them with the grey
as well after the first coat gray is dried I just dry brush everything with
the lighter gray to pick up some highlights now the fun part the
artificial water I use an acrylic kit by a company called simple life you can
find it out Walmart in the floral section it's basically the exact same
thing as the stuff they sell at Michaels but for a fraction of the price take
equal parts from each bottle and mix them together for a pond this size one
cap of each is about the perfect amount and that's why I like these shallow
pools it makes your resident go a lot further
while still looking good once your two parts are mixed up you can
carefully pour it into the tile I find using a soft plastic cup for this gives
me enough control over the pour you want to make sure the entire surface of the
pool is covered so you don't end up with any dry spots and if you need to you can
tilt the tile back and forth a little bit to move the resin into any voids
once poured you can have some fun with some extra embellishments an alternative
to gluing in place and rocks beforehand is just to paint some out and drop them
into the resin I also like to add a bit of plant life to my water you can do
this with small clump foliage just put in as much or as little as you want
I actually like to use more than one size of clump foliage and more than one
color this stuff here is a little bit darker and a little bit thicker than the
first stuff I put in for some really nice detail you can take tiny tiny
pieces from those lights in clumps you get at the craft store I take tiny tiny
little veins and very sparingly drop them in to represent some weeds three or
four little veins will look really awesome and once you're happy with
everything put the tile aside somewhere safe and let it sit for a solid 48 hours
to harden up you can see just how awesome these look for a very little
cost also experiment with different color techniques I like to do some in
all green for a more kind of swampy algae infested look that's it for this
episode if you guys liked the tutorial please
give me a like and drop a comment below if you haven't already done so please
hit subscribe I've also got a black magic crafts Facebook page where I post
progress photos of various things I'm working
we'll see you again in Episode six Cheers
